stem: A 47-year-old client who underwent an open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of a tibial fracture 6 hours ago reports increasing pain in the affected leg that is unresponsive to opioid analgesics. The nurse assesses the client and reviews the electronic health record (EHR). Based on the information provided, which of the following findings indicate the client is developing acute compartment syndrome? Select all that apply.

options.text: Client reports pain is 10/10, even after administration of IV morphine 4mg.
options.rationale: Severe pain out of proportion to the injury, especially pain that is not relieved by opioid analgesics, is a hallmark sign of compartment syndrome due to increasing pressure on nerve endings within the compartment.

options.text: Capillary refill in the toes of the affected leg is less than 3 seconds.
options.rationale: A capillary refill of less than 3 seconds is a normal finding and does not indicate compartment syndrome. While later stages might involve vascular compromise, early compartment syndrome primarily affects nerve function.

options.text: Client reports a pins-and-needles sensation in the affected leg.
options.rationale: Paresthesia, often described as a pins-and-needles sensation, is an early neurological sign of compartment syndrome caused by increased pressure on the nerves within the affected compartment.

options.text: Palpable pedal pulse in the affected leg.
options.rationale: The presence of a palpable pedal pulse does not rule out compartment syndrome, especially in the early stages. Pulselessness is a late sign, indicating significant vascular compromise.

options.text: The affected leg is noticeably swollen and feels firm to the touch.
options.rationale: Swelling and a tight, firm feeling in the affected compartment are indicative of increased pressure within the compartment, a key characteristic of compartment syndrome.

options.text: Client is able to dorsiflex and plantarflex the foot without difficulty.
options.rationale: While early on the client might have some movement, pain will increase on passive stretching of the affected muscles. Inability to move the extremity is a later finding. Early on, pain with movement is more common.

itemContext.SBAR: 07:00, Nurse Jones calling about Mr. Smith in room 302. He's a 47-year-old male, post-op ORIF tibia fracture, 6 hours ago. He's reporting increasing pain in his left leg, rated 10/10, unrelieved by morphine 4mg IV given 30 minutes ago. The leg is increasingly swollen and firm. He reports tingling in his toes. Capillary refill is <3 seconds, pedal pulse palpable. Situation: Severe pain despite analgesics, potential compartment syndrome. Background: ORIF tibia fracture 6 hours ago. Pain was controlled initially. Assessment: Pain 10/10, swelling, firmness, paresthesia. Pulses present, cap refill <3 sec. Recommendation: I think the patient is developing compartment syndrome and needs immediate evaluation by the surgical team. I am also concerned about potential nerve damage given the tingling.
itemContext.Vitals: BP: 130/80 mmHg, HR: 90 bpm, RR: 18, SpO2: 98% on room air, Temp: 37.0°C (98.6°F)
itemContext.Radiology: Post-operative X-ray confirms proper alignment of the fracture.
itemContext.MAR: Morphine 4mg IV Q4H PRN Pain (Last dose given 06:30)

clinicalPearls: Compartment syndrome is a surgical emergency. Early recognition and intervention (fasciotomy) are crucial to prevent permanent muscle and nerve damage. The '6 Ps' (Pain, Pallor, Paresthesia, Paralysis, Pulselessness, Poikilothermia) are classic signs, but pain out of proportion to injury and paresthesia are often the earliest indicators.
questionTrap: Many students may incorrectly select 'palpable pedal pulse' as an indication of no compartment syndrome. However, the presence of a pulse does NOT rule out compartment syndrome, especially in its early stages. Pulselessness is a LATE sign.
mnemonic: The 6 P's of Compartment Syndrome: Pain (out of proportion), Pallor, Paresthesia, Paralysis, Pulselessness, Poikilothermia (coolness). Remember: Pain and Paresthesia are often the EARLY signs.
